heisigComment: * As a primitive, it can mean either yawn or lack.
heisigStory: The pictograph hidden in this character is of someone yawning. The first stroke shows the head thrown back; the second, the arm bent at the elbow as the hand reaches up to cover the mouth; and the last two, the legs. Since yawning shows a lack of something (psychologically, interest; physiologically, sleep), the connection is plain to see.
hint: lack of pain in the lower part of the spine
koohiiStory1: To me, this kanji looks like a person with two arms and two legs, but who lacks a head.
koohiiStory2: When your body lacks oxygen you yawn.
readingExamples: 欠く (か.く), 欠ける (か.ける)
words: to lack, to break, to crack, to chip
